questionTypes.queText: What is the most effective response?
What is the least effective response?

options.text: Ask the female employee if she borrowed his pen and let her response determine what he should do next.
Send a group e-mail to the other employees in his office area asking if they have seen his pen or know where it might be.
Reclaim his pen from the female employee's work area when she is not around.
Inform his manager that one of his coworkers was looking through his work area and stole his pen.
Continue training the employee on the computer program and then help Teresa when training is finished.
Give the instruction manual to the trainee and ask him to become familiar with the program.
Provide training on the basics of the computer program with the time available.
Inform Teresa that her request will conflict with an already-assigned task and discuss the options.
Let Jim know that she was reprimanded by management because of him.
Offer strategies to Jim for completing the reports more efficiently and provide assistance as needed.
Equally divide the remaining reports that need to be completed between herself and Jim.
Determine the reason for the lack of Jim's productivity.
Repeat his sentence to show his co-worker that it is grammatically correct.
Tell his co-worker that she needs to stop being defensive about her writing in order to finish this letter.
Allow his co-worker to use her sentence in the letter, but remind her that the letter is a team effort.
Propose that they use a different sentence that is a compromise of both their sentences.
Again apologize to the client and indicate that she understands the customer's frustration.
Request that the client calm down and lower her voice so that she might explain the situation.
Inform the client that Greg failed to call her and that this mistake will not happen in the future.
Explain to the client that mistakes sometimes happen, and that it was not her fault.
Complete the tasks as best as possible and ask the manager for clarification when he returns.
Seek out the assistance of coworkers to clarify the manager's instructions.
Let the manager know that all of his instructions were not understood and then ask follow up questions for clarification.
Tell manager the instructions he gave were unclear, and then ask him to provide the instructions in writing.
Ignore Amanda's comments and carry on with the current discussion.
Immediately tell Amanda that it would be appreciated if her comments are more business related.
Immediately tell Amanda that her comments are inappropriate and apologize to the client for her comments.
Direct the conversation to a more appropriate subject and later speak with Amanda in private about her comments with the client.
Ask the client to hold while he checks on the vice president's availability and informs him of the situation.
Attempt to take a message and have the vice president call the client back later.
Forward the call to the vice president's voicemail.
Tell the client that he will not put the call through to the vice president unless the client calms down and acts appropriately.
During the meeting, explain to him that his interruptions are disrespectful and unprofessional.
Shortly after the meeting, tell him that his interruptions were rude during the meeting.
During the meeting, politely ask him not to speak until she finishes her comments.
Interrupt him the next time he speaks so that she can finish her remarks.
Attempt to place the call on hold and explain to the new client about the disgruntled people he has to deal with.
Immediately hang up on the caller and assist the new client.
Attempt to place the call on hold and apologize to the new client and provide her assistance.
Ask the new client if she would mind taking a seat for the moment while he resolves the issue with the caller on the phone.
Write out a set of instructions for Russell to follow when attempting this particular task.
Require Russell to figure it out for himself.
Reprimand Russell for not paying attention and let him know that this type of attitude will not be tolerated.
Repeat the instructions after asking Russell to pay closer attention and take notes.
Ask him to coordinate with others assigned to the same project and receive their approval before his suggestions can be implemented.
Update the project plans based upon his suggestions.
Thank him for his suggestions, but tell him that his suggestions cannot be included in the current plan because the schedule has already been finalized.
Tell him that he should take his suggestions to his supervisor and let the supervisor decide whether his suggestions should be included.
Do nothing and ignore what was said.
Ask them to please stop discussing issues involving their co-workers while at work.
E-mail them asking them to please stop talking about other employees.
Tell Erik that co-workers were saying negative things about him.
Inform both employees that their manager will be closely monitoring their interactions with one another.
Hold a meeting with both employees together in an attempt to resolve the reasons for their conflict.
Ignore the potential conflict between team members and move forward on the project.
Meet with team members to discuss the importance of working cooperatively on this project.
Tell his co-worker to read the manual and do the best she can.
Inform the person he is meeting for lunch that he will be delayed and stay to assist the co-worker.
Tell his co-worker that he needs to leave, but will provide assistance when he returns from lunch.
Suggest to the co-worker that she ask her manager for an extension to the deadline.
Speak loudly when taking his own calls to show his co-worker what she sounds like.
Tell his co-worker to take her personal calls outside of the office.
Ask his co-worker to speak more quietly when talking on the phone.
Get a pair of headphones to reduce the noise from the co-worker's phone calls.
Express her concerns to her manager about the new employee's lack of interest.
Tell the new employee that he had better get his act together or she will inform the Chief Executive Officer of his poor effort.
Remind the new employee about the importance of organization and keeping good records.
Do nothing since the new employee has connections to the Chief Executive Officer.
Make a joke to lighten the conversation.
Decide which employee is in the wrong.
Criticize the employees for their poor attitudes.
Direct the focus of the employees toward completing the task at hand.
Continue with the meeting and speak to the late employee afterwards to give him the information he missed.
Provide a quick recap of the missed information so that the late employee will be up to date on the most current company policies without feeling left behind.
Restart the meeting from the beginning to make sure that everyone has heard all of the information.
Immediately ask the employee why he was late.
Inform Robert that she has previous obligations and ask for guidance on which task she should perform first.
Prioritize the assignments in terms of importance and complete the more important of the two assignments.
Continue working on her current task and complete Robert's tasks if she has time.
Attempt to delegate some of her responsibilities to a less busy co-worker in order to complete both assignments.
Ask Dante about his specific reason for wanting to meet with the boss and then determine if the reason requires a meeting.
Ask the boss if she is available to meet with Dante about a personal matter.
Ask Dante to read the section in the employee handbook that covers these issues.
Tell Dante that he must make an appointment and receive clearance from his supervisor.
Share the feedback she has received from current customers and surveys.
Explain to the manager that his reasoning is incorrect.
Assume the manager has already considered all options and say nothing.
Approach the manager after the meeting and then share her thoughts about the distribution method.
Leave the breakroom with the new employee and apologize for any comments he may have heard.
Immediately tell the two employees that their comments are inappropriate.
Attempt to change the subject to a discussion that is more appropriate.
Tell the new employee to avoid talking to these two employees because they spread gossip.
Watch the employee in the future to ensure that he is not gambling.
Provide information about a local gambling problem support group.
Accept his apology and ask him to assist her as requested.
Ask him not to gamble when he is supposed to be helping her.
Tell the other employees that he is too busy to help them.
Only assist the co-worker who is having trouble with the copy machine.
Complete the tasks in the order they were requested.
Briefly assist his co-workers before returning to the initial task.
